text.front:
First results and planned experiments with the
INFN-LNS ray-tracing magnetic spectrometer
MAGNEX
A.Cunsolo
a,b , F.Cappuzzello
a,b , M.Cavallaro
a,b , A.Foti
c
, S.E.A.Orrigo
a,b ,
M.R.D.Rodrigues
b T.Borello-Lewin
d , H.Petrascu
e , D.Carbone
a
a
Dipartimento di Fisica e Astronomia, Università di Catania, Catania, Italy
b
INFN-Laboratori Nazionali del Sud, Catania, Italy
c INFN-Sezione di Catania, Catania, Italy
d IFUSP,S.Paolo,Brazil
e NIPNE, Bucarest, Romania
Abstract. The MAGNEX large-acceptance ray-tracing magnetic spectrometer has recently been
used with beams from the INFN-LNS Tandem accelerator. After an accurate commissioning, the
instrument has started an ambitious experimental program. In the first experiment the
19 F
(7 Li,
7 Be)
19
O charge-exchange reaction was studied at 52 MeV incident energy. The
19
O
excitation energy spectrum was reconstructed and the angular distributions measured. The
second experiment was aimed at the study of the
15 C via the
13
C(
18
O,
16 O)
15 C reaction at 84 MeV
incident energy. The ejectiles where detected at forward angles and mass identified by means of
an innovative technique. The
15
C excitation energy spectra up to about 20 MeV were obtained
with a 250 keV FWHM energy resolution. In addition to several known states, the spectra show
two unknown resonant-like structures at 11.4 and 14.0 MeV. The strong population of these
structures, together with the measured widths, could indicate the collective nature of these states
associated to a correlated neutron pair transfer. Besides the first results of physical interest from
these two experiments, future experiments with MAGNEX are briefly outlined.
Keywords: Magnetic spectrometers. Spectroscopy of light nuclei.
PACS: 07.81.+a, 07.77.Ka, 29.30.Ep, 29.40.-n, 21.10.Pc, 21.10.Re, 25.70.Hi
text.body:
INTRODUCTION
The MAGNEX large-acceptance magnetic spectrometer [1-2] has been
commissioned and recently used in experiments performed with beams by the INFN-
LNS Tandem. MAGNEX has been designed particularly for applications where the
counting rate is expected to be rather low and the experimental information is required
to be very clean. Experiments with stable beams from both the Tandem and the
Superconducting Cyclotron (CS) have been foreseen, as well as one based on the use
with RNBs from the EXCYT facility at the LNS. The spectrometer relies partly on
hardware (especially the shape of the entrance and exit dipole pole tips) and partly on
software (ray reconstruction) to overcome the strong aberrations inherent in the 50-

– and the optics in general, were tested with elastically scattered

based on inverse-matrices calculated from the complicated 3D-interpolation of the
measured fields [3-4]. A demonstration of the particle identification capabilities of the
PSD start detector [5] and the focal plane detector (FPD) [6-7] was given by a
measurement of the

19 O charge exchange reaction at 25 ± 5º, using the full
acceptance of the spectrometer. The charge state distribution of
48 Ti ions scattered at
120 MeV was also measured and found to be in good agreement with the predictions
of INTENSITY [8]. The overall angular and energy resolution measured after the
application of ray reconstruction algorithms agree with the prediction of the
simulations. Fig.1 shows the general view of the Spectrometer.
FIGURE 1. General view of the MAGNEX spectrometer. From the left to the right the scattering
chamber, the quadrupole, the dipole and the Focal Plane Detector are visible.
THE MOTIVATION OF THE FIRST EXPERIMENT
In the last years, the study of nuclear structure and reaction dynamics far off the
stability valley has attracted much interest from both the theoretical and experimental
sides. The present study of the
19 O neutron-rich nucleus via the (
7 Li,
7 Be) charge-
exchange reaction is well inserted into this context.
The investigation of this nucleus belongs to a research line that aims at a systematic
exploration of structural properties of light neutron-rich nuclei, for which an inner core
of an integer number of α particles is coupled to three external neutrons (Nα + 3
neutrons). The (
7 Li,
7 Be) reaction at about 8 MeV/A incident energy has shown to be a
suitable tool to explore such systems, as demonstrated by previous studies on other

nuclei belonging to this category:
11 Be and
15 C [9-10]. In fact, this process in such
energy range proceeds with a predominance of the direct one-step mechanism,
resulting in an useful probe for spectroscopic studies. In addition, it turned out to be
suitable to populate configurations more complex than the single-particle ones,
providing, thanks also to the good resolution that can be achieved, complementary
information on nuclear structure. Therefore the first experiment performed with
MAGNEX was the
19 F
(7 Li,
7 Be)
19 O charge-exchange reaction at 52 MeV, in order to
investigate the
19 O nucleus , i.e. the N = 4 member.
EXPERIMENTAL DETAILS
The 52.2 MeV
7 Li
+++ beam was accelerated by the Tandem facility of the INFN-
LNS. The
19
F target was a 80 μg/cm
2 thick AlF 3 foil evaporated on a gold backing of
250 μg/cm
2 . A
27
Al target (116 μg/cm
2 ) was also used in order to estimate and subtract
the aluminium contribution in the final spectra. Supplementary runs were done also on
a WO 3 target (150 μg/cm
2
on 20 μg/cm
2 carbon backing) and on a carbon target (76
μg/cm
2 ) with the same purpose. The reaction ejectiles were momentum analyzed by
MAGNEX. The quadrupole and dipole fields and the α-surface coil, together with the
position of the FPD, were set in order to focus the
7 Be ejectiles associated to the
19 O g.s.
in the focal plane position corresponding to a momentum deviation δ = 0.08 with
respect to the central one. The FPD is an hybrid detector consisting of a gas section
followed by a Si detector hodoscope. The gas section consists of two couples of two
Drift chambers spaced by a proportional chamber. It was filled with 99.95% pure
isobutane gas at 10 mbar pressure. The cathode was supplied –950 V, while the Frish-
grid was grounded. The high voltage in the proportional wires was +750 V, and the
lateral shaping wires between the Frish-grid and the proportional wires were
maintained at increasing voltage by a separate power supply at +400 V. The 45 silicon
detectors, each 500 µm thick, cover the back of the FPD and were powered with +60
V voltage in a full depletion mode. To identify the ions the PSD start detector was not
needed. The data analyzed up to now were taken when the spectrometer was located at
a central angle of

large angular acceptance of MAGNEX (horizontally –0.090 rad, +0.110 rad,

19 O EXCITATION ENERGY SPECTRA
The identification of the
7 Be ejectiles was done by the MAGNEX Focal Plane
Detector through a ΔE-E technique combined with the measurement of the magnetic
rigidity vs. the kinetic energy of each detected particle [11]. An algebraic technique of
ray-reconstruction of the detected ions [3-4] has been used to relate the final
parameters measured at the focal plane to the initial phase space parameters. Such ray-

text.body:
reconstruction technique is based on the formalism of Differential Algebra [12]. This
technique is used to solve the differential equations describing the motion of ions
through the spectrometer and to obtain the Taylor coefficients of the flow linking the
initial phase space with the final one. In this mathematic environment, the integration
of the differential equations results in a simpler algebraic task, therefore very high
order of the perturbation series can be treated. With this technique, if the appropriate
position and direction of the detected ion is accurately measured at the focal plane, one
can reconstruct (i.e. trace) the ion trajectory back to the reaction target and
consequently obtain the scattering angles (polar and azimuthal) and the initial
momentum of the ion, by the application of the inverse map of the measured phase
space parameters.

In Fig.2 a reconstructed spectrum of the
19 O excitation energy is shown. In
detail the spectrum obtained from the data with the AlF 3 target is shown
superimposed the one relative to the aluminium target. Several
19 O excited states

7 Be ejectiles are in the 0.43
MeV first excited state. Most of the
19 O states have been observed in the past by
one and two neutron transfer reactions (see [13] and reference therein), thus
confirming the capability of the (
7 Li,
7 Be) reactions to populate such states. For

THE (
7 LI,
7 BE) ANGULAR DISTRIBUTIONS
One of the advantages when working with a large acceptance spectrometer is that,
in a single setting of the instrument, several scattering angles are covered. Therefore, a
consistent part of the angular distributions relative to the transitions associated to the
detected ejectiles can be measured at once, i.e. in the same experimental conditions,
resulting in a reduction of the normalisation uncertainty. In the present case, a single
set of measurements at central angle
°
= 25

12
lab
θ
allows to obtain angular
distributions for scattering angles in the range 10° < θ CM < 21° in the centre of mass
reference frame. In Fig. 3 the measured angular distributions for the transition to the
not resolved doublet of
19 O ground and first excited state at 0.096 MeV is shown. In
Fig. 4 the angular distribution for the transition to the
19 O(1.47MeV, ½
+ ) excited state
is shown.
A theoretical analysis of the
19 F(
7 Li,
7 Be)
19 O reaction in the framework of the
Charge-Exchange Quasi-particle Random Phase Approximation (CEX-QRPA) [14] is
on the way [15]. This approach is very powerful since it can be used to describe the
19 O nuclear structure and also to calculate the transition densities connecting the
19 F
ground to the 1p-1h states of
19 O, thus allowing a direct connection to reaction cross
section calculations by a suitable Distorted Wave Born Approximation (DWBA). The
use of a realistic semi-microscopic interaction, that includes the tensor contribution, in
both structure and reaction calculations, has allowed in the past to describe very well
reactions similar to the present one as the
11 B(
7 Li,

11 Be and
15 N(

15 C in the
same energy region [9-10].

THE MOTIVATION OF THE SECOND EXPERIMENT
The
15
C nucleus is a neutron rich system which has stimulated an increasing
spectroscopic interest in the years (see [16-17] and references therein). A simple
representation of the low lying states with positive parity can be established within the
1p-2h space, i.e. a sd-shell neutron coupled to the
14
C ground state. Differently for the
negative parity states, where the 2p-3h space with the inclusion of the supplemental

done in the past by transfer reactions [16]. In addition a clear evidence of the effect of
the core polarisation has been found in charge exchange reactions by the appearance
of Fano resonances at about 8.4 MeV excitation energy [10]. The present experiment
represent a new attempt to study the
15 C spectra by the use of the (
18 O,
16
O) transfer
reaction at 84 MeV. It is known that, at incident energies about 7.5 times the Coulomb
barrier the angular distributions of multi nucleon transfer reactions are sensitive to the
details of the final populated states [18-19]. Under these conditions, according to the
Brink's energy and angular momentum matching conditions [20], one expects to
excite significantly states with L = 0, 2 and 4.
EXPERIMENTAL DETAILS
The experiment has been performed in two steps, first in January 2008 and after in
March 2009, at the INFN-LNS Laboratory of Catania. In the first run a restricted
angular range between 18° and 40° in the CM reference frame was covered. In the
second, the range was enlarged from 9° to 50° and a supplemental target of
12 C was
used. In this paper we report on the first run, being the analysis of the second still
under way. The
18 O beam bombarded a 140 µg/cm
2 self supporting
13 C target at 84
MeV incident energy. The Oxygen ions produced in the collisions were detected by
the MAGNEX spectrometer with the purpose to study the structure of
14 C,
15
C and
16
C
nuclei via the (
18 O,
17,16,15
O) multi-neutron transfer reactions. The magnetic fields were
set in order to accept the Oxygen ions with charge between 6
+ to 8
+ at the maximum
kinetic energy. These were identified by the simultaneous measurement of their
position along the focal plane and their residual energy on the silicon detector
hodoscope.

ions are identified by comparison with loci expected from kinematics and energy loss calculations. The
selection condition for the Oxygen ions is also drawn. In the right panel the focal plane position is

In Fig.5 an example of the identification capabilities of the instrument is shown.
This result indicates that, for many cases the particle identification can be successfully
obtained without the standard measurement of the time of flight as discussed in ref.
[8]. After gating on the
16 O
8+ ejectiles, the horizontal and vertical positions and angles
at the focal plane are analyzed, thus providing the constraints for the application of the
high order algorithms of trajectory reconstruction, implemented in the spectrometer.
As said before, this procedure does allow for the reconstruction of interesting physical
quantities as the scattering angle and the excitation energy of the target residual. An
example of obtained bi-dimensional histogram correlating these quantities is shown in
Fig.6. In the plot several vertical lines are evident, especially at low excitation energy.
These indicate the population of discrete states and narrow resonances of the
15 C. One
should also note the achieved independence of the reconstructed excitation energy
from the scattering angle. By projecting the same data on the abscissa, as done in
Fig.7, one gets the energy of these states. Several peaks are recognized as due to
transitions to known states of
15 C, namely the ground and states at excitation energy of
0.74, 3.1, 4.22, 4.66, 6.84 and 7.35 MeV. Deviations between the measured energies
and the known ones are within 50 keV. Two broad structures are observed with
energies centered at about 11.4 and 14.0 MeV and FWHM of 2 and 2.5 MeV,
respectively. A systematic error of about 1 MeV originated by the underlying
background is estimated for these latter. These are unknown from literature and
represent an interesting finding of the experiment.

In Fig.8a the angular distribution of the resonance at 11.4 MeV is compared with
that of the 1/2
-
resonance at 3.103 MeV, which is almost a pure L = 0 transition from
the 1/2

C ground state [16-17]. Similarly in Fig.8b the same comparison is done
with the angular distribution for the L = 3 transition to the 5/2
+ bound state at 0.74
MeV. A similar behavior is observed between the transition to the 11.4 MeV
resonance and the L = 0 one, while deviations are observed with the L = 3 one, at least
as regards the slope of the curves. Similar deviations are observed in the comparison
with the L = 4 transitions to the 7/2
-
,9/2
- states at 6.84 and 7.35 MeV. As regards the
resonance at 14.0 MeV it behaves exactly as the one at 11.4 MeV, indicating that very
likely the physical origin of both is the same. Taking all of this into account one can
infer that the L = 0 transfer seems to be the angular momentum transferred for the
population of the resonances at 11.4 and 14.0 MeV.

E x = 11.45 MeV and at E x = 3.103 MeV (L = 0). b) Comparison of the measured angular distributions
for the transition to the resonance at E x = 11.45 MeV and to the bound state at E x = 0.74 MeV (L = 3).
It is also interesting to note in Fig.8a that the cross section for the resonances at
11.4 and 14.0 MeV are about one order of magnitude larger than that at 3.1 MeV,
clearly showing that a large amount of the L = 0 strength is exhausted in the former.
Since the state at 3.1 MeV is an almost pure 2p-1h state, one can conclude about the
collective nature of these resonances. To summarize, the dominance of the two
neutron transfer mechanism compared to the single neutron transfer has been
observed. This indicates the dominance of the pair transfer compared to the second
order process of sequential transfer of two uncorrelated neutrons in such experimental
conditions. In addition it seems that a collective L = 0 degree of freedom has been

FUTURE PLANNED EXPERIMENTS
The future experiments involving MAGNEX and approved by the INFN-LNS
PAC are the following ones: THM, Multineutron, Nuclear Rainbow, CEX, α-
MAGNEX and
8 He states.
The first one concerns the measurement of the
12
C +
12 C fusion cross section at
energies of astrophysical interest via the Trojan Horse Method [21]. In this case the
system studied will be
16 O+
12 C at 26 MeV incident energy, being the Trojan Horse the
16 O nucleus. If, in the target nucleus field, it breaks in an α particle, which is emitted
at forward angles (the spectator) and detected by means of MAGNEX, the correlated
12
C nucleus will interact and mainly fuse with the
12 C target. The α particle or protons
evaporated by the
24 Mg Compound Nucleus, will be detected in coincidence with the
spectator by means of a couple of position sensitive silicon telescopes. The
coincidence cross sections will allow to extract the
12 C +
12 C (participants) one. The
THM experiment is planned in November of the current year.
The (
18 O,
16 O) Multineutron experiment will be aimed to complete the angular
distribution measurements already done, including zero degrees, as well as to extend,
at the same incident energy, the measurements on
9 Be,
14 C and
15 N targets. It is
planned on March 2010.
Also the (
7 Li,
7 Be) angular distributions, already measured, will be completed
including the zero degrees measurements and extended to
24 Mg and
28 Si targets in the
CEX experiment planned in April 2010. In fact, the proportionality between the
measured cross section at zero degrees and the β-decay strengths for Gamow-Teller
(GT) transitions, or with the equivalent ones measured via corresponding (n,p) or
(p,n) reactions at energies above 100 MeV, is considered a proof of almost pure direct
one-step reaction mechanism.
The Nuclear Rainbow experiment will concern the measurement of the elastic
scattering of the reaction
27 Al(
16 O,
16 O)
27 Al at 100 MeV incident energy, in order to
verify the presence of characteristic " Rainbow " pattern [22]. This experiment has
been recently suggested by IFUSP and IFF colleagues, on the basis of calculations
done in the framework of the Sao Paulo Potential procedure and will be performed in
February 2010. It is a quite challenging experiment, because the elastically scattered
16 O nuclei should be measured up to very large angles, where very low yield is
expected.
The α-MAGNEX experiment is aimed to investigate the α-cluster states in medium
– heavy nuclei populated via the (
6 Li,d) reaction at E 6Li = 40 MeV and verify the
theoretical prediction based on a convolution potential. As it implies the detection of
high energy deuterons, some up-grading of the FPD is needed . Therefore it is planned
in the 2011.
The
8 He states experiment foresees the
8 Li radioactive beam from the EXCYT-LNS
facility impinging on a
7 Li target. The spectrometer will detect the
7 Be ions, emitted in
the CEX
7 Li(
8 Li,
7 Be)
8 He reaction at MeV incident energy. This will allow to measure
